author: kwiknick
body:
This change is to fix Issue #3148 - Update copyright notices. 
Changed the ManagedEntranceStrings resource file to take in a parameter.  Then edited the ManagedEntrance.cs to grab the year using GetDate.Now and placing it in the banner variable for display when powershell is opened.

comments.body: Maybe we don't even need the year, that would be even simpler.

I can change it to not have a year, but I was trying to fulfill what was asked in Issue #3148.  There are no concerns of legal implications if the date isn't in there?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Currently all MSFT applications use a year in copyright (cmd.exe, notepad.exe, skype...)

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
But they do not use a dynamic year - e.g. `cmd.exe` says `(c) 2016 Microsoft Corporation.` on my machine right now.

We can follow up, but it might just be a historical thing, or copying a pattern.  There was a move to remove the copyright year from source files at one point.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It seems that this (year) is tied to the main release time. I agree that is _internal_ MSFT pattern. Perhaps it has historical legal roots.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Aye, we need @joeyaiello and @SteveL-MSFT to weigh in on the legal question.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I'll follow up on this.

comments.author: kwiknick
comments.body: Thanks for all the comments and feedback.  I out of habit brought my fork up to upstream/master, which, as it's supposed to, kicked off the CI builds.  I didn't change any of the code I submitted.  I'm just big on keeping my branch, fork in this case, up to date in order to limit merge conflicts.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
Just so I understand, is the date dynamically generated at build time or runtime? If I had to guess, I think runtime is probably problematic, but that's just a hunch. 

Either way, I'm sending off the mail to legal now

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @joeyaiello I've already started a conversation with legal

comments.author: kwiknick
comments.body: @joeyaiello It is generated at runtime, which I can see how/why It'd be problematic.  If legal decides that they want the date, I'll get it to generate at build time.  I should've done that in the first place.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
Just found that `dotnet publish` with the RC4 dotnet CLI doesn't have the year in coryright banner now:
```
PS:53> dotnet publish -f netcoreapp1.0 -c release
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 15.1.545.13942
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

  console -> X:\arena\apps\console\bin\release\netcoreapp1.0\console.dll
```
powershell should go this direction too.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: We'll ask if that's an option to legal as well

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: For legal too: What copyright we should use in the files? These files have been published under MIT. There are also new files.

comments.author: kwiknick
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT That's great news!  I'll update it this evening and push the changes.  Thanks everyone for all the collaboration.

comments.author: kwiknick
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT the changes have been made and this is ready for review.  Thanks for being so helpful.

comments.author: kwiknick
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT  Thanks for catching the unnecessary string.Formats.  I forgot to remove them as well a couple using statements.   The way I read the code when I first forked it, was that it shows a different banner based on the OS of the machine.  Do you want me to remove that as well and just have it to be the same message regardless?

comments.body: I remember that @lzybkr open PR to remove Windows PowerShell from the repo so I believe we should remove the non-Core banner.
